docs.lead_paragraph: A WALK through the streets around Times Square reveals the shame of New York: little children who grow up in welfare hotels, their playground the city's physical and moral filth. They are destined for life in the underclass of welfare, drugs and crime. The society that now averts its eyes will later see them as a permanent burden and threat. These children are victims of a callousness unequaled in any other Western democracy. Though their plight is more visible, Times Square's children are merely symptoms of a national neglect of poor children everywhere. Last month, Harold Howe 2d, in a report to the National Association of School Psychologists, called for the creation of a National Children's Center and an agenda to give childhood in America a passport to humanity.

headline.main: A Passport to Humanity For Nation's Children
